column2: The next morning he had more of a struggle than ever to wash and dress her.
column3: The next morning he had more of a struggle than ever to wash and dress her.

column2: Indeed at one time nothing but holding her by the scruff prevented her from getting away from him, but at last he achieved his object and she was washed, brushed, scented and dressed, although to be sure this left him better pleased than her, for she regarded her silk jacket with disfavour.
column3: Indeed at one time nothing but holding her by the scruff prevented her from getting away from him, but at last he achieved his object and she was washed, brushed, scented and dressed, although to be sure this left him better pleased than her, for she regarded her silk jacket with disfavour.

column2: Still at breakfast she was well mannered though a trifle hasty with her food.
column3: Still at breakfast she was well mannered though a trifle hasty with her food.

column2: Then his difficulties with her began for she would go out, but as he had his housework to do, he could not allow it.
column3: Then his difficulties with her began for she would go out, but as he had his housework to do, he could not allow it.

column2: He brought her picture books to divert her, but she would have none of them but stayed at the door scratching it with her claws industriously till she had worn away the paint.
column3: He brought her picture books to divert her, but she would have none of them but stayed at the door scratching it with her claws industriously till she had worn away the paint.

column2: At first he tried coaxing her and wheedling, gave her cards to play patience and so on, but finding nothing would distract her from going out, his temper began to rise, and he told her plainly that she must wait his pleasure and that he had as much natural obstinacy as she had. But to all that he said she paid no heed whatever but only scratched the harder.
column3: At first he tried coaxing her and wheedling, gave her cards to play patience and so on, but finding nothing would distract her from going out, his temper began to rise, and he told her plainly that she must wait his pleasure and that he had as much natural obstinacy as she had. But to all that he said she paid no heed whatever but only scratched the harder.

column2: Thus he let her continue until luncheon, when she would not sit up, or eat off a plate, but first was for getting on to the table, and when that was prevented, snatched her meat and ate it under the table. To all his rebukes she turned a deaf or sullen ear, and so they each finished their meal eating little, either of them, for till she would sit at table he would give her no more, and his vexation had taken away his own appetite.
column3: Thus he let her continue until luncheon, when she would not sit up, or eat off a plate, but first was for getting on to the table, and when that was prevented, snatched her meat and ate it under the table. To all his rebukes she turned a deaf or sullen ear, and so they each finished their meal eating little, either of them, for till she would sit at table he would give her no more, and his vexation had taken away his own appetite.

column2: In the afternoon he took her out for her airing in the garden.
column3: In the afternoon he took her out for her airing in the garden.

column2: She made no pretence now of enjoying the first snowdrops or the view from the terrace.
column3: She made no pretence now of enjoying the first snowdrops or the view from the terrace.

column2: No--there was only one thing for her now--the ducks, and she was off to them before he could stop her.
column3: No-there was only one thing for her now-the ducks, and she was off to them before he could stop her.

column2: Luckily they were all swimming when she got there (for a stream running into the pond on the far side it was not frozen there).
column3: Luckily they were all swimming when she got there (for a stream running into the pond on the far side it was not frozen there).

column2: When he had got down to the pond, she ran out on to the ice, which would not bear his weight, and though he called her and begged her to come back she would not heed him but stayed frisking about, getting as near the ducks as she dared, but being circumspect in venturing on to the thin ice.
column3: When he had got down to the pond, she ran out on to the ice, which would not bear his weight, and though he called her and begged her to come back she would not heed him but stayed frisking about, getting as near the ducks as she dared, but being circumspect in venturing on to the thin ice.

column2: Presently she turned on herself and began tearing off her clothes, and at last by biting got off her little jacket and taking it in her mouth stuffed it into a hole in the ice where he could not get it.
column3: Presently she turned on herself and began tearing off her clothes, and at last by biting got off her little jacket and taking it in her mouth stuffed it into a hole in the ice where he could not get it.

column2: Then she ran hither and thither a stark naked vixen, and without giving a glance to her poor husband who stood silently now upon the bank, with despair and terror settled in his mind.
column3: Then she ran hither and thither a stark naked vixen, and without giving a glance to her poor husband who stood silently now upon the bank, with despair and terror settled in his mind.

column2: She let him stay there most of the afternoon till he was chilled through and through and worn out with watching her.
column3: She let him stay there most of the afternoon till he was chilled through and through and worn out with watching her.

column2: At last he reflected how she had just stripped herself and how in the morning she struggled against being dressed, and he thought perhaps he was too strict with her and if he let her have her own way they could manage to be happy somehow together even if she did eat off the floor.
column3: At last he reflected how she had just stripped herself and how in the morning she struggled against being dressed, and he thought perhaps he was too strict with her and if he let her have her own way they could manage to be happy somehow together even if she did eat off the floor.

column2: So he called out to her then:
column3: So he called out to her then:

column2: Silvia, come now, be good, you shan't wear any more clothes if you don't want to, and you needn't sit at table neither, I promise.	Silvia, come now, be good, you shan't wear any more clothes if you don't want to, and you needn't sit at table neither, I promise.
column3: true

column2: You shall do as you like in that, but you must give up one thing, and that is you must stay with me and not go out alone, for that is dangerous.
column3: You shall do as you like in that, but you must give up one thing, and that is you must stay with me and not go out alone, for that is dangerous.

column2: If any dog came on you he would kill you."
column3: If any dog came on you he would kill you."

column2: Directly he had finished speaking she came to him joyously, began fawning on him and prancing round him so that in spite of his vexation with her, and being cold, he could not help stroking her.
column3: Directly he had finished speaking she came to him joyously, began fawning on him and prancing round him so that in spite of his vexation with her, and being cold, he could not help stroking her.

column2: Oh, Silvia, are you not wilful and cunning?	Oh, Silvia, are you not wilful and cunning?
column3: true

column2: I see you glory in being so, but I shall not reproach you but shall stick to my side of the bargain, and you must stick to yours."
column3: I see you glory in being so, but I shall not reproach you but shall stick to my side of the bargain, and you must stick to yours."

column2: He built a big fire when he came back to the house and took a glass or two of spirits also, to warm himself up, for he was chilled to the very bone.
column3: He built a big fire when he came back to the house and took a glass or two of spirits also, to warm himself up, for he was chilled to the very bone.

column2: Then, after they had dined, to cheer himself he took another glass, and then another, and so on till he was very merry, he thought. Then he would play with his vixen, she encouraging him with her pretty sportiveness.
column3: Then, after they had dined, to cheer himself he took another glass, and then another, and so on till he was very merry, he thought. Then he would play with his vixen, she encouraging him with her pretty sportiveness.

column2: He got up to catch her then and finding himself unsteady on his legs, he went down on to all fours.
column3: He got up to catch her then and finding himself unsteady on his legs, he went down on to all fours.

column2: The long and the short of it is that by drinking he drowned all his sorrow; and then would be a beast too like his wife, though she was one through no fault of her own, and could not help it.
column3: The long and the short of it is that by drinking he drowned all his sorrow; and then would be a beast too like his wife, though she was one through no fault of her own, and could not help it.

column2: To what lengths he went then in that drunken humour I shall not offend my readers by relating, but shall only say that he was so drunk and sottish that he had a very imperfect recollection of what had passed when he woke the next morning.
column3: To what lengths he went then in that drunken humour I shall not offend my readers by relating, but shall only say that he was so drunk and sottish that he had a very imperfect recollection of what had passed when he woke the next morning.

column2: There is no exception to the rule that if a man drink heavily at night the next morning will show the other side to his nature.
column3: There is no exception to the rule that if a man drink heavily at night the next morning will show the other side to his nature.

column2: Thus with Mr. Tebrick, for as he had been beastly, merry and a very dare-devil the night before, so on his awakening was he ashamed, melancholic and a true penitent before his Creator.
column3: Thus with mr Tebrick, for as he had been beastly, merry and a very dare devil the night before, so on his awakening was he ashamed, melancholic and a true penitent before his Creator.

column2: The first thing he did when he came to himself was to call out to God to forgive him for his sin, then he fell into earnest prayer and continued so for half-an-hour upon his knees.
column3: The first thing he did when he came to himself was to call out to God to forgive him for his sin, then he fell into earnest prayer and continued so for half an hour upon his knees.

column2: Then he got up and dressed but continued very melancholy for the whole of the morning.
column3: Then he got up and dressed but continued very melancholy for the whole of the morning.

column2: Being in this mood you may imagine it hurt him to see his wife running about naked, but he reflected it would be a bad reformation that began with breaking faith.
column3: Being in this mood you may imagine it hurt him to see his wife running about naked, but he reflected it would be a bad reformation that began with breaking faith.

column2: He had made a bargain and he would stick to it, and so he let her be, though sorely against his will.
column3: He had made a bargain and he would stick to it, and so he let her be, though sorely against his will.

column2: For the same reason, that is because he would stick to his side of the bargain, he did not require her to sit up at table, but gave her her breakfast on a dish in the corner, where to tell the truth she on her side ate it all up with great daintiness and propriety.
column3: For the same reason, that is because he would stick to his side of the bargain, he did not require her to sit up at table, but gave her her breakfast on a dish in the corner, where to tell the truth she on her side ate it all up with great daintiness and propriety.

column2: Nor she did make any attempt to go out of doors that morning, but lay curled up in an armchair before the fire dozing.
column3: Nor she did make any attempt to go out of doors that morning, but lay curled up in an armchair before the fire dozing.

column2: After lunch he took her out, and she never so much as offered to go near the ducks, but running before him led him on to take her a longer walk.
column3: After lunch he took her out, and she never so much as offered to go near the ducks, but running before him led him on to take her a longer walk.

column2: This he consented to do very much to her joy and delight.
column3: This he consented to do very much to her joy and delight.

column2: He took her through the fields by the most unfrequented ways, being much alarmed lest they should be seen by anyone.
column3: He took her through the fields by the most unfrequented ways, being much alarmed lest they should be seen by anyone.

column2: But by good luck they walked above four miles across country and saw nobody.
column3: But by good luck they walked above four miles across country and saw nobody.

column2: All the way his wife kept running on ahead of him, and then back to him to lick his hand and so on, and appeared delighted at taking exercise.
column3: All the way his wife kept running on ahead of him, and then back to him to lick his hand and so on, and appeared delighted at taking exercise.

column2: And though they startled two or three rabbits and a hare in the course of their walk she never attempted to go after them, only giving them a look and then looking back to him, laughing at him as it were for his warning cry of "Puss! come in, no nonsense now!"
column3: And though they startled two or three rabbits and a hare in the course of their walk she never attempted to go after them, only giving them a look and then looking back to him, laughing at him as it were for his warning cry of "Puss! come in, no nonsense now!"

column2: Just when they got home and were going into the porch they came face to face with an old woman.
column3: Just when they got home and were going into the porch they came face to face with an old woman.

column2: Mr. Tebrick stopped short in consternation and looked about for his vixen, but she had run forward without any shyness to greet her.
column3: mr Tebrick stopped short in consternation and looked about for his vixen, but she had run forward without any shyness to greet her.

column2: Then he recognised the intruder, it was his wife's old nurse.
column3: Then he recognised the intruder, it was his wife's old nurse.

column2: What are you doing here, Mrs. Cork? he asked her.
column3: What are you doing here, mrs Cork? he asked her.

column2: Mrs. Cork answered him in these words:
column3: mrs Cork answered him in these words:

column2: Poor thing.	Poor thing.
column3: true

column2: Poor Miss Silvia!
column3: Poor Miss Silvia!

column2: It is a shame to let her run about like a dog.
column3: It is a shame to let her run about like a dog.

column2: It is a shame, and your own wife too.
column3: It is a shame, and your own wife too.

column2: But whatever she looks like, you should trust her the same as ever.
column3: But whatever she looks like, you should trust her the same as ever.

column2: If you do she'll do her best to be a good wife to you, if you don't I shouldn't wonder if she did turn into a proper fox.
column3: If you do she'll do her best to be a good wife to you, if you don't I shouldn't wonder if she did turn into a proper fox.

column2: I saw her, sir, before I left, and I've had no peace of mind.
column3: I saw her, sir, before I left, and I've had no peace of mind.

column2: I couldn't sleep thinking of her.
column3: I couldn't sleep thinking of her.

column2: So I've come back to look after her, as I have done all her life, sir," and she stooped down and took Mrs. Tebrick by the paw.
column3: So I've come back to look after her, as I have done all her life, sir," and she stooped down and took mrs Tebrick by the paw.

column2: Mr. Tebrick unlocked the door and they went in.
column3: mr Tebrick unlocked the door and they went in.

column2: When Mrs. Cork saw the house she exclaimed again and again: "The place was a pigstye.
column3: When mrs Cork saw the house she exclaimed again and again: "The place was a pigstye.

column2: They couldn't live like that, a gentleman must have somebody to look after him.
column3: They couldn't live like that, a gentleman must have somebody to look after him.

column2: She would do it.
column3: She would do it.

column2: He could trust her with the secret."
column3: He could trust her with the secret."

column2: Had the old woman come the day before it is likely enough that Mr. Tebrick would have sent her packing.
column3: Had the old woman come the day before it is likely enough that mr Tebrick would have sent her packing.

column2: But the voice of conscience being woken in him by his drunkenness of the night before he was heartily ashamed of his own management of the business, moreover the old woman's words that "it was a shame to let her run about like a dog," moved him exceedingly.
column3: But the voice of conscience being woken in him by his drunkenness of the night before he was heartily ashamed of his own management of the business, moreover the old woman's words that "it was a shame to let her run about like a dog," moved him exceedingly.

column2: Being in this mood the truth is he welcomed her.
column3: Being in this mood the truth is he welcomed her.

column2: But we may conclude that Mrs. Tebrick was as sorry to see her old Nanny as her husband was glad.
column3: But we may conclude that mrs Tebrick was as sorry to see her old Nanny as her husband was glad.

column2: If we consider that she had been brought up strictly by her when she was a child, and was now again in her power, and that her old nurse could never be satisfied with her now whatever she did, but would always think her wicked to be a fox at all, there seems good reason for her dislike.
column3: If we consider that she had been brought up strictly by her when she was a child, and was now again in her power, and that her old nurse could never be satisfied with her now whatever she did, but would always think her wicked to be a fox at all, there seems good reason for her dislike.

column2: And it is possible, too, that there may have been another cause as well, and that is jealousy.
column3: And it is possible, too, that there may have been another cause as well, and that is jealousy.

column2: We know her husband was always trying to bring her back to be a woman, or at any rate to get her to act like one, may she not have been hoping to get him to be like a beast himself or to act like one?
column3: We know her husband was always trying to bring her back to be a woman, or at any rate to get her to act like one, may she not have been hoping to get him to be like a beast himself or to act like one?

column2: May she not have thought it easier to change him thus than ever to change herself back into being a woman?
column3: May she not have thought it easier to change him thus than ever to change herself back into being a woman?

column2: If we think that she had had a success of this kind only the night before, when he got drunk, can we not conclude that this was indeed the case, and then we have another good reason why the poor lady should hate to see her old nurse?
column3: If we think that she had had a success of this kind only the night before, when he got drunk, can we not conclude that this was indeed the case, and then we have another good reason why the poor lady should hate to see her old nurse?

column2: It is certain that whatever hopes Mr. Tebrick had of Mrs. Cork affecting his wife for the better were disappointed.
column3: It is certain that whatever hopes mr Tebrick had of mrs Cork affecting his wife for the better were disappointed.

column2: She grew steadily wilder and after a few days so intractable with her that Mr. Tebrick again took her under his complete control.
column3: She grew steadily wilder and after a few days so intractable with her that mr Tebrick again took her under his complete control.

column2: The first morning Mrs. Cork made her a new jacket, cutting down the sleeves of a blue silk one of Mrs. Tebrick's and trimming it with swan's down, and directly she had altered it, put it on her mistress, and fetching a mirror would have her admire the fit of it.
column3: The first morning mrs Cork made her a new jacket, cutting down the sleeves of a blue silk one of mrs Tebrick's and trimming it with swan's down, and directly she had altered it, put it on her mistress, and fetching a mirror would have her admire the fit of it.

column2: All the time she waited on Mrs. Tebrick the old woman talked to her as though she were a baby, and treated her as such, never thinking perhaps that she was either the one thing or the other, that is either a lady to whom she owed respect and who had rational powers exceeding her own, or else a wild creature on whom words were wasted.
column3: All the time she waited on mrs Tebrick the old woman talked to her as though she were a baby, and treated her as such, never thinking perhaps that she was either the one thing or the other, that is either a lady to whom she owed respect and who had rational powers exceeding her own, or else a wild creature on whom words were wasted.

column2: But though at first she submitted passively, Mrs. Tebrick only waited for her Nanny's back to be turned to tear up her pretty piece of handiwork into shreds, and then ran gaily about waving her brush with only a few ribands still hanging from her neck.
column3: But though at first she submitted passively, mrs Tebrick only waited for her Nanny's back to be turned to tear up her pretty piece of handiwork into shreds, and then ran gaily about waving her brush with only a few ribands still hanging from her neck.

column2: So it was time after time (for the old woman was used to having her own way) until Mrs. Cork would, I think, have tried punishing her if she had not been afraid of Mrs. Tebrick's rows of white teeth, which she often showed her, then laughing afterwards, as if to say it was only play.
column3: So it was time after time (for the old woman was used to having her own way) until mrs Cork would, I think, have tried punishing her if she had not been afraid of mrs Tebrick's rows of white teeth, which she often showed her, then laughing afterwards, as if to say it was only play.

column2: Not content with tearing off the dresses that were fitted on her, one day Silvia slipped upstairs to her wardrobe and tore down all her old dresses and made havoc with them, not sparing her wedding dress either, but tearing and ripping them all up so that there was hardly a shred or rag left big enough to dress a doll in.
column3: Not content with tearing off the dresses that were fitted on her, one day Silvia slipped upstairs to her wardrobe and tore down all her old dresses and made havoc with them, not sparing her wedding dress either, but tearing and ripping them all up so that there was hardly a shred or rag left big enough to dress a doll in.

column2: On this, Mr. Tebrick, who had let the old woman have most of her management to see what she could make of her, took her back under his own control.
column3: On this, mr Tebrick, who had let the old woman have most of her management to see what she could make of her, took her back under his own control.

column2: He was sorry enough now that Mrs. Cork had disappointed him in the hopes he had had of her, to have the old woman, as it were, on his hands.
column3: He was sorry enough now that mrs Cork had disappointed him in the hopes he had had of her, to have the old woman, as it were, on his hands.

column2: True she could be useful enough in many ways to him, by doing the housework, the cooking and mending, but still he was anxious since his secret was in her keeping, and the more now that she had tried her hand with his wife and failed.
column3: True she could be useful enough in many ways to him, by doing the housework, the cooking and mending, but still he was anxious since his secret was in her keeping, and the more now that she had tried her hand with his wife and failed.

column2: For he saw that vanity had kept her mouth shut if she had won over her mistress to better ways, and her love for her would have grown by getting her own way with her.
column3: For he saw that vanity had kept her mouth shut if she had won over her mistress to better ways, and her love for her would have grown by getting her own way with her.

column2: But now that she had failed she bore her mistress a grudge for not being won over, or at the best was become indifferent to the business, so that she might very readily blab.
column3: But now that she had failed she bore her mistress a grudge for not being won over, or at the best was become indifferent to the business, so that she might very readily blab.

column2: For the moment all Mr. Tebrick could do was to keep her from going into Stokoe to the village, where she would meet all her old cronies and where there were certain to be any number of inquiries about what was going on at Rylands and so on.
column3: For the moment all mr Tebrick could do was to keep her from going into Stokoe to the village, where she would meet all her old cronies and where there were certain to be any number of inquiries about what was going on at Rylands and so on.

column2: But as he saw that it was clearly beyond his power, however vigilant he might be, to watch over the old woman and his wife, and to prevent anyone from meeting with either of them, he began to consider what he could best do.
column3: But as he saw that it was clearly beyond his power, however vigilant he might be, to watch over the old woman and his wife, and to prevent anyone from meeting with either of them, he began to consider what he could best do.

column2: Since he had sent away his servants and the gardener, giving out a story of having received bad news and his wife going away to London where he would join her, their probably going out of England and so on, he knew well enough that there would be a great deal of talk in the neighbourhood.
column3: Since he had sent away his servants and the gardener, giving out a story of having received bad news and his wife going away to London where he would join her, their probably going out of England and so on, he knew well enough that there would be a great deal of talk in the neighbourhood.

column2: And as he had now stayed on, contrary to what he had said, there would be further rumour.
column3: And as he had now stayed on, contrary to what he had said, there would be further rumour.

column2: Indeed, had he known it, there was a story already going round the country that his wife had run away with Major Solmes, and that he was gone mad with grief, that he had shot his dogs and his horses and shut himself up alone in the house and would speak with no one.
column3: Indeed, had he known it, there was a story already going round the country that his wife had run away with Major Solmes, and that he was gone mad with grief, that he had shot his dogs and his horses and shut himself up alone in the house and would speak with no one.

column2: This story was made up by his neighbours not because they were fanciful or wanted to deceive, but like most tittle-tattle to fill a gap, as few like to confess ignorance, and if people are asked about such or such a man they must have something to say, or they suffer in everybody's opinion, are set down as dull or "out of the swim." In this way I met not long ago with someone who, after talking some little while and not knowing me or who I was, told me that David Garnett was dead, and died of being bitten by a cat after he had tormented it.
column3: This story was made up by his neighbours not because they were fanciful or wanted to deceive, but like most tittle tattle to fill a gap, as few like to confess ignorance, and if people are asked about such or such a man they must have something to say, or they suffer in everybody's opinion, are set down as dull or "out of the swim." In this way I met not long ago with someone who, after talking some little while and not knowing me or who I was, told me that David Garnett was dead, and died of being bitten by a cat after he had tormented it.

column2: He had long grown a nuisance to his friends as an exorbitant sponge upon them, and the world was well rid of him.
column3: He had long grown a nuisance to his friends as an exorbitant sponge upon them, and the world was well rid of him.

column2: Hearing this story of myself diverted me at the time, but I fully believe it has served me in good stead since.
column3: Hearing this story of myself diverted me at the time, but I fully believe it has served me in good stead since.

column2: For it set me on my guard as perhaps nothing else would have done, against accepting for true all floating rumour and village gossip, so that now I am by second nature a true sceptic and scarcely believe anything unless the evidence for it is conclusive.
column3: For it set me on my guard as perhaps nothing else would have done, against accepting for true all floating rumour and village gossip, so that now I am by second nature a true sceptic and scarcely believe anything unless the evidence for it is conclusive.

column2: Indeed I could never have got to the bottom of this history if I had believed one tenth part of what I was told, there was so much of it that was either manifestly false and absurd, or else contradictory to the ascertained facts.
column3: Indeed I could never have got to the bottom of this history if I had believed one tenth part of what I was told, there was so much of it that was either manifestly false and absurd, or else contradictory to the ascertained facts.

column2: It is therefore only the bare bones of the story which you will find written here, for I have rejected all the flowery embroideries which would be entertaining reading enough, I daresay, for some, but if there be any doubt of the truth of a thing it is poor sort of entertainment to read about in my opinion.
column3: It is therefore only the bare bones of the story which you will find written here, for I have rejected all the flowery embroideries which would be entertaining reading enough, I daresay, for some, but if there be any doubt of the truth of a thing it is poor sort of entertainment to read about in my opinion.

column2: To get back to our story: Mr. Tebrick having considered how much the appetite of his neighbours would be whetted to find out the mystery by his remaining in that part of the country, determined that the best thing he could do was to remove.
column3: To get back to our story: mr Tebrick having considered how much the appetite of his neighbours would be whetted to find out the mystery by his remaining in that part of the country, determined that the best thing he could do was to remove.

column2: After some time turning the thing over in his mind, he decided that no place would be so good for his purpose as old Nanny's cottage.
column3: After some time turning the thing over in his mind, he decided that no place would be so good for his purpose as old Nanny's cottage.

column2: It was thirty miles away from Stokoe, which in the country means as far as Timbuctoo does to us in London.
column3: It was thirty miles away from Stokoe, which in the country means as far as Timbuctoo does to us in London.

column2: Then it was near Tangley, and his lady having known it from her childhood would feel at home there, and also it was utterly remote, there being no village near it or manor house other than Tangley Hall, which was now untenanted for the greater part of the year.
column3: Then it was near Tangley, and his lady having known it from her childhood would feel at home there, and also it was utterly remote, there being no village near it or manor house other than Tangley Hall, which was now untenanted for the greater part of the year.

column2: Nor did it mean imparting his secret to others, for there was only Mrs. Cork's son, a widower, who being out at work all day would be easily outwitted, the more so as he was stone deaf and of a slow and saturnine disposition.
column3: Nor did it mean imparting his secret to others, for there was only mrs Cork's son, a widower, who being out at work all day would be easily outwitted, the more so as he was stone deaf and of a slow and saturnine disposition.

column2: To be sure there was little Polly, Mrs. Cork's granddaughter, but either Mr. Tebrick forgot her altogether, or else reckoned her as a mere baby and not to be thought of as a danger.
column3: To be sure there was little Polly, mrs Cork's granddaughter, but either mr Tebrick forgot her altogether, or else reckoned her as a mere baby and not to be thought of as a danger.

column2: He talked the thing over with Mrs. Cork, and they decided upon it out of hand.
column3: He talked the thing over with mrs Cork, and they decided upon it out of hand.

column2: The truth is the old woman was beginning to regret that her love and her curiosity had ever brought her back to Rylands, since so far she had got much work and little credit by it.
column3: The truth is the old woman was beginning to regret that her love and her curiosity had ever brought her back to Rylands, since so far she had got much work and little credit by it.

column2: When it was settled, Mr. Tebrick disposed of the remaining business he had at Rylands in the afternoon, and that was chiefly putting out his wife's riding horse into the keeping of a farmer near by, for he thought he would drive over with his own horse, and the other spare horse tandem in the dogcart.
column3: When it was settled, mr Tebrick disposed of the remaining business he had at Rylands in the afternoon, and that was chiefly putting out his wife's riding horse into the keeping of a farmer near by, for he thought he would drive over with his own horse, and the other spare horse tandem in the dogcart.

column2: The next morning they locked up the house and they departed, having first secured Mrs. Tebrick in a large wicker hamper where she would be tolerably comfortable.
column3: The next morning they locked up the house and they departed, having first secured mrs Tebrick in a large wicker hamper where she would be tolerably comfortable.

column2: This was for safety, for in the agitation of driving she might jump out, and on the other hand, if a dog scented her and she were loose, she might be in danger of her life.
column3: This was for safety, for in the agitation of driving she might jump out, and on the other hand, if a dog scented her and she were loose, she might be in danger of her life.

column2: Mr. Tebrick drove with the hamper beside him on the front seat, and spoke to her gently very often.
column3: mr Tebrick drove with the hamper beside him on the front seat, and spoke to her gently very often.

column2: She was overcome by the excitement of the journey and kept poking her nose first through one crevice, then through another, turning and twisting the whole time and peeping out to see what they were passing. It was a bitterly cold day, and when they had gone about fifteen miles they drew up by the roadside to rest the horses and have their own luncheon, for he dared not stop at an inn.
column3: She was overcome by the excitement of the journey and kept poking her nose first through one crevice, then through another, turning and twisting the whole time and peeping out to see what they were passing. It was a bitterly cold day, and when they had gone about fifteen miles they drew up by the roadside to rest the horses and have their own luncheon, for he dared not stop at an inn.

column2: He knew that any living creature in a hamper, even if it be only an old fowl, always draws attention; there would be several loafers most likely who would notice that he had a fox with him, and even if he left the hamper in the cart the dogs at the inn would be sure to sniff out her scent.
column3: He knew that any living creature in a hamper, even if it be only an old fowl, always draws attention; there would be several loafers most likely who would notice that he had a fox with him, and even if he left the hamper in the cart the dogs at the inn would be sure to sniff out her scent.

column2: So not to take any chances he drew up at the side of the road and rested there, though it was freezing hard and a north-east wind howling.
column3: So not to take any chances he drew up at the side of the road and rested there, though it was freezing hard and a north-east wind howling.

column2: He took down his precious hamper, unharnessed his two horses, covered them with rugs and gave them their corn.
column3: He took down his precious hamper, unharnessed his two horses, covered them with rugs and gave them their corn.

column2: Then he opened the basket and let his wife out.
column3: Then he opened the basket and let his wife out.

column2: She was quite beside herself with joy, running hither and thither, bouncing up on him, looking about her and even rolling over on the ground.
column3: She was quite beside herself with joy, running hither and thither, bouncing up on him, looking about her and even rolling over on the ground.

column2: Mr. Tebrick took this to mean that she was glad at making this journey and rejoiced equally with her.
column3: mr Tebrick took this to mean that she was glad at making this journey and rejoiced equally with her.

column2: As for Mrs. Cork, she sat motionless on the back seat of the dogcart well wrapped up, eating her sandwiches, but would not speak a word.
column3: As for mrs Cork, she sat motionless on the back seat of the dogcart well wrapped up, eating her sandwiches, but would not speak a word.

column2: When they had stayed there half-an-hour Mr. Tebrick harnessed the horses again, though he was so cold he could scarcely buckle the straps, and put his vixen in her basket, but seeing that she wanted to look about her, he let her tear away the osiers with her teeth till she had made a hole big enough for her to put her head out of.
column3: When they had stayed there half an hour mr Tebrick harnessed the horses again, though he was so cold he could scarcely buckle the straps, and put his vixen in her basket, but seeing that she wanted to look about her, he let her tear away the osiers with her teeth till she had made a hole big enough for her to put her head out of.

column2: They drove on again and then the snow began to come down and that in earnest, so that he began to be afraid they would never cover the ground.
column3: They drove on again and then the snow began to come down and that in earnest, so that he began to be afraid they would never cover the ground.

column2: But just after nightfall they got in, and he was content to leave unharnessing the horses and baiting them to Simon, Mrs. Cork's son.
column3: But just after nightfall they got in, and he was content to leave unharnessing the horses and baiting them to Simon, mrs Cork's son.

column2: His vixen was tired by then, as well as he, and they slept together, he in the bed and she under it, very contentedly.
column3: His vixen was tired by then, as well as he, and they slept together, he in the bed and she under it, very contentedly.

column2: The next morning he looked about him at the place and found the thing there that he most wanted, and that was a little walled-in garden where his wife could run in freedom and yet be in safety.
column3: The next morning he looked about him at the place and found the thing there that he most wanted, and that was a little walled in garden where his wife could run in freedom and yet be in safety.

column2: After they had had breakfast she was wild to go out into the snow.
column3: After they had had breakfast she was wild to go out into the snow.

column2: So they went out together, and he had never seen such a mad creature in all his life as his wife was then.
column3: So they went out together, and he had never seen such a mad creature in all his life as his wife was then.

column2: For she ran to and fro as if she were crazy, biting at the snow and rolling in it, and round and round in circles and rushed back at him fiercely as if she meant to bite him.
column3: For she ran to and fro as if she were crazy, biting at the snow and rolling in it, and round and round in circles and rushed back at him fiercely as if she meant to bite him.

column2: He joined her in the frolic, and began snowballing her till she was so wild that it was all he could do to quiet her again and bring her indoors for luncheon.
column3: He joined her in the frolic, and began snowballing her till she was so wild that it was all he could do to quiet her again and bring her indoors for luncheon.

column2: Indeed with her gambollings she tracked the whole garden over with her feet; he could see where she had rolled in the snow and where she had danced in it, and looking at those prints of her feet as they went in, made his heart ache, he knew not why.
column3: Indeed with her gambollings she tracked the whole garden over with her feet; he could see where she had rolled in the snow and where she had danced in it, and looking at those prints of her feet as they went in, made his heart ache, he knew not why.
